oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presidential Medal of Freedom Certificate
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hooks, Benjamin L.; Bush, George W.; Presidential Medal of Freedom; presidents; civil rights; NAACP;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A certificate, signed by President George W. Bush, awarding Benjamin L. Hooks the Presidential Medal of Freedom. "As a minister, lawyer, judge and public servant, Benjamin Hooks has dedicated his life to equal justice under law. A pioneer of the Civil Rights movement and a leader of the NAACP, he fought to extend the full promise of America to all its citizens..." Awarded on November 5, 2007, at the White House.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Group shot with NAACP National Headquarters plaque
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hooks, Benjamin L.; NAACP; portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Benjamin Hooks poses with four unidentified men and a plaque commemorating the NAACP National Headquarters. The plaque reads: "For 77 years the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was housed in New York City where it rented office space in more than 7 different locations. In 1977, the Board of Directors approved a proposal to investigate the feasibility of purchasing a permanent home for the NAACP. -- In 1985, the Board approved the purchase of this building as the permanent home for the NAACP. A formal dedication was held October 16-19, 1986. -- The building was purchased under the leadership of Benjamin L. Hooks, Executive Director. Officers were Kelly M. Alexander, Sr. who served as Chairman until his death in 1985. William F. Gibson succeeded him as Chairman, Jesse M. Turner, Treasurer, and Enola P. McMillan, National President. -- The NAACP expresses appreciation to its staff, particularly Reverend Jerry M. Guess and J. Howard Henderson for their untiring efforts, sacrifice and dedication toward the culmination of the move and renovation of our national headquarters."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2015, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Benjamin Hooks at the New York Hilton
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hooks, Benjamin L.; NAACP; sports; African Americans; New York; portraits; 1980s;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note on back reads, "On Wednesday, April 15, 1987, at the New York Hilton, Dr. Benjamin L. Hooks, Executive Director of the NAACP, held a press conference to unveil the Association's plans to investigate the lack of blacks in front office positions in baseball, basketball, and football. Dr. Hooks met with 20 representatives of NAACP branches located in cities with major league franchises. The branches will request meetings with the owners of the professional teams in their city in order to formulate strategies on how to increase more black representation in managerial positions. In the rear, NAACP staff looks on. From left to right are Mrs. Enolia McMillan, president; Howard Henderson, Director of Administration; Hazel Dukes, President of the New York State Conference; and William Penn, Director of Branch and Field Services."
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2015, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. While the Memphis Public Library & Information Center may house an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law.
